I agree with what you say here, but I don't think you addressed the best arguments people have against non-binary. To me, the biggest issue is that I get the sense that people who are nonbinary are simply people who don't fit into any stereotypical gender role, but that doesn't make them not the gender they were born in. Wearing dresses, pink and long hair may be stereotypically feminine, but they are not inherently womanly and sports, short hair and general aggression are stereotypically masculine, but not inherently manly. I get the sense that nonbinary people are saying that if you don't fit into the stereotype for one gender, then you are somewhere in between, but I disagree. I can be incredibly masculine but that doesn't make me any less of a woman, and same for men. It seems like nonbinary are actually enforcing gender roles by implying that if you don't fit into one gender role, you are not that gender. I have yet to hear anyone explain/refute this.   The reason I say I believe in only two genders is that no one has been able to articulate the difference between a person who doesn't fit into stereotypical gender roles and someone who is nonbinary. Obviously, I believe everyone should be treated with respect no matter what, but I simply don't understand nonbinary identities. However, I am absolutely open to hearing what anyone has to say on the matter.

I get it it mostly depends from your style, but I felt you set the bar of the argument too low: you start with arguments 'against' non-binary gender (already a quite ill defined frame), but then you reply to the tougher arguments by moving to discuss the 'existence' of non-binary genders. Once you define a gender as 'what I feel like', there is no reason to discuss that question: I cannot discuss if someone does or doesn't feel non binary, everyone agrees on it. I wouldn't say this is a complete strawman - there are indeed comments on youtube claiming that those people are wrong in believing something - but it's setting the bar on the very uneducated. More interesting and more debated questions is if it is important to recognize those different genders in our society, if there are chemical basis (as there are for gender dysphoria), if it is useful to change our vocabulary to accomodate their need. These are the debated points, and I believe you failed to answer by shifting the bar to just saying: 'Well, if they feel like non-binary, how can we say it is not the case?'. I go more in detail. I don't think there is any doubt that gender, like everything outside abstract thinking, is non-binary. Even for the bits of the computer the binary representation is just an approximation of an analogical state. There is clearly, even in our hardcore binary evolutionary nature, someone falling in the middle. Or on the side. The point is to decide, as for the bits of the computer, if the binary representation is a good enough representation for our use, or if we want to change it in favor of analogical one. Personally, if any change is required, I would abolish gender-specific societal characteristics instead of multiplying them. A good example is the pronouns. If there was enough evidence for misuse of pronouns being a problem for enough people, and that this problem would weight more in society with respect to the diffused advantage of using gendered pronouns, I could understand a campaign to slowly remove gender-specific pronouns and moving just to 'it' for things and 'they' for people. The multiplication instead is hardly a proficient strategy.  Not because of traditions or language stability, but for the grammatical role of pronouns. Pronoun, pro-noun, means 'instead of the name'. It is a short part you use to avoid repetition and to make discussion faster when it is clear which is the substituted name. You can indeed always substitute he, she or it for the noun, 'He is blond' -> 'Peter is blond', but often it would become cumbersome 'He lost his book. It is red.' -> 'Peter lost Peter's book. Peter's book is red.' The distinction between it and he/she is useful because it makes communication easier: often, there is someone and something in the scene, and the use of it and he/she helps clarity. If I were to remove the distinction between he and it, to say 'He lost his book. He is red.' would be confusing about what is red, him or the book. The lack of distinction would force me to use more repetitions. Same for the gendered distinction between he and she, as it is often the case that gender is well defined and it helps shortening sentences that involve one man and one woman. If however this is not the case, because for example human interactions are not anymore based on male and female interaction or because we consider that this binary representation of reality is not relevant often enough, or because we think that avoiding people to be unconfortable with their non-binary state is more important than an efficient communication, it is much better to remove gendered pronouns than to multiply it.  Why? Because if we move to an analogical approach to gender, everyone is different. Everyone has their own interpretation of their gender. If everyone has their preferred pronouns, they are useless: everyone already has a unique pro-noun: their noun, i,e. their name. If my pronouns are xyr xim, and you have to ask them to me, isn't it easier to just say 'bobon123' and 'bobon123's'? The pronouns are useful only if they are simple and they work on a vast majority of cases. If they are personal, they are just nicknames. Ok, first things first. It is obvious that gender identity doesn't map one-to-one with biological sex. That's a given, unless you're Ben Shapiro. But saying that it doesn't map on-to-one with biological sex is different from saying that the two are entirely unrelated and they have nothing to do with one another. That's just historically and linguistically false... or is it just a coincidence that 99% biological females identify as females and 99% biological males identify as males?

Of course gender relates to biological sex, which is binary... But ok, I'm eager to accept the idea that, despite an incredibly strong tendency of gender identity and biological sex to overlap, they are indeed apples and oranges and they are not related in any meaningful way. And I might even go out of my way and accept that there are like three, four or fourteen genders out there.
Ok.

And what would that mean, exactly? What IS gender, anyway? I was used to understand gender as a cultural construct based on attributes of masculinity and femininity, i.e. as a binary system by definition. It is born as a binary system, based on a binary biological classification, built in order to define a binary system of roles... yeah, yeah, I guess you can change that, too; after all it's just word and its meaning can change.

So, ok, let's go for it, let's change gender from a binary system to a quaternary system or whatever. But when you change the meaning of a word to such an extent that it has no relationship with its original purpose you have to deal with the fact that people are already accustomed to a certain frame of meaning and you will have to expect some resistence, not because they are stupid conservatives but because you are asking a big change in their customs and in their way to perceive and cathegorize things.

But this is not the true problem, either. The true problem is that this new way to understand gender is utterly useless. The point of a binary classification system is: you sacrifice detailed descriptions of particular entities for the sake of manageability in terms of classes. That's the point of all our modeling of reality, that's the point of language itself: you classify things in a small number of cathegories so that they become manageable. Male and female: two classes, two words conveying some meaningful information about their memers (at the very least, what they look like). Genders are manageable because they are two and no more, you can't have fourteen genders, and not because it would be a crime against nature, but because fourteen genders fail to make things manageable. Ok, you can think of taking binarism away from gender... but you'll find out there's nothing left to it afterwards.

Just think of it for a moment: I have this gender classification that has no roots in biology. This means that not only I can't use it to tell if the other person is, e.g., fit for a certain job, but neither if they have a penis or a vagina, id est if they are a potential sexual partner. I feel the overwhelming uselessness of this gender classification already. And not only that: I also have to learn fourteen of these useless genders. And possibly fourteen pronouns, too.
And none of them tells me, like, NOTHING about the other person.
